title: Adidas se disculpa después de que México criticó su zapato inspirado en huaraches de Oaxaca
description: Después del lanzamiento del zapato, los políticos en México acusaron al diseñador, Willy Chavarria, y a Adidas de apropiación cultural del trabajo de los artesanos.
content:
Adidas se disculpa después de que México criticó su zapato inspirado en huaraches de Oaxaca Después del lanzamiento del zapato, los políticos en México acusaron al diseñador, Willy Chavarria, y a Adidas de apropiación cultural del trabajo de los artesanos. Diseñado por Willy Chavarria, el modelo Adidas Oaxaca slip-on se parece a un huarache, una sandalia tradicional fabricada por los artesanos zapotecas de Oaxaca, México. 11 de agosto de 2025 a las

Willy Chavarria, diseñador de moda estadounidense, dijo que quería honrar la cultura mexicoestadounidense cuando creó la Adidas Oaxaca slip-on. La sandalia tiene una suela negra gruesa que Adidas utilizó en un modelo de zapatilla para senderismo que salió en la década de 1990 y una parte superior negra tejida que recuerda a la de un huarache oaxaqueño, una sandalia tradicional fabricada por artesanos zapotecas en Oaxaca, México. “Para mí es un híbrido entre mi trabajo y Adidas, y es como la combinación perfecta”, declaró la semana pasada al sitio web Sneakers News. “Con calcetines blancos, es literalmente una de las referencias chicanas más clásicas”. Pero cuando el modelo salió a la venta la semana pasada, algunos políticos en México acusaron a Chavarria y a Adidas de “apropiación cultural”. La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, mostró una imagen de las sandalias Adidas Oaxaca slip-ons en su conferencia de prensa del viernes y dijo que Adidas y otras empresas estaban “usurpando la creatividad” de las comunidades indígenas. Dijo que el gobierno de Oaxaca había iniciado conversaciones con Adidas para reembolsar a las comunidades indígenas por el uso de su “propiedad intelectual colectiva” y que México estaba dispuesto a emprender acciones legales. Chavarria, hijo de madre irlandesaestadounidense y padre mexicanoestadounidense, emitió el sábado una disculpa, escrita en inglés y español y dirigida “al pueblo de Oaxaca”. “La intención siempre fue honrar el poderoso espíritu cultural y artístico de Oaxaca y sus comunidades creativas, un lugar cuya belleza y resistencia me han inspirado”, dijo Chavarria. “El nombre ‘Oaxaca’ no es solo una palabra: es cultura viva, es gente y es historia”. “Lamento profundamente que el zapato se haya apropiado de este diseño y no se haya desarrollado en colaboración directa y significativa con la comunidad oaxaqueña”, añadió. “Esto no está a la altura del respeto y la colaboración que Oaxaca, la comunidad zapoteca de Villa Hidalgo Yalalag y su pueblo merecen”. Villa Hidalgo es una localidad oaxaqueña donde se fabrican huaraches. Adidas señaló en un comunicado que “reconoce y valora la riqueza cultural de las comunidades indígenas de México y el significado de su herencia artesanal”. “El Oaxaca slip-on se inspiró en un diseño de Oaxaca, arraigado en la tradición de Villa Hidalgo Yalalag”, dijo la empresa. “Ofrecemos una disculpa pública y reafirmamos nuestro compromiso de colaborar con Yalalag en un diálogo respetuoso que honre su legado cultural”. Chavarria dijo que “la intención siempre fue honrar el poderoso espíritu cultural y artístico de Oaxaca y sus comunidades creativas” . Adidas no respondió cuando se le preguntó si la sandalia se seguía vendiendo. La obra de Chavarria ha explorado a menudo la cultura mexicoestadounidense, la sexualidad y la migración, basándose en su experiencia al crecer en una comunidad agrícola de California. Su padre era trabajador migrante. Chavarria, quien fue vicepresidente sénior de Calvin Klein, dijo a Sneaker News la semana pasada que le gustaba trabajar con grandes marcas como Adidas porque le ayudaban a amplificar su mensaje de “dignidad humana”. “Me hace sentir muy orgulloso trabajar con una empresa que realmente respeta y eleva la cultura de la forma más genuina”, dijo. Salomón Jara Cruz, gobernador de Oaxaca, dijo que la sandalia era un “plagio” cultural. “El patrimonio cultural material e inmaterial de nuestros pueblos tiene que ser reconocido y respetado”, dijo en las redes sociales. Las autoridades mexicanas tienen un historial de defensa celosa de los diseños tradicionales frente a lo que consideran usos inapropiados por parte de foráneos. La Secretaría de Cultura de México dijo en 2019 que se sorprendió al descubrir que una silla colorida fabricada por la casa de moda Louis Vuitton incluía diseños de artistas mexicanos de Hidalgo. En respuesta, la marca dijo que estaba trabajando con artesanos del estado “con la perspectiva de colaborar juntos en la producción de esta colección”. Ese mismo año, Alejandra Frausto, entonces secretaria de Cultura de México, escribió una carta a Carolina Herrera, la marca de moda neoyorquina, acusándola de utilizar técnicas de bordado y patrones de comunidades indígenas mexicanas en la colección resort 2020 de la marca. La línea de ropa incluía bordados florales y de pájaros en vestidos sin tirantes, abrigos de piel perforada y vestidos de fiesta. En respuesta, Wes Gordon, director creativo de la marca, declaró a The New York Times que la empresa estaba estudiando qué medidas tomar. “Estamos viviendo un gran cambio social en la forma de hablar sobre género, cultura e identidad”, dijo Gordon. “Son debates importantes. Nos lo tomamos muy en serio”. Michael Levenson cubre noticias de última hora para el Times desde Nueva York.
translation:
Adidas apologized after Mexico criticized his shoe inspired by Huaraches of Oaxaca after the launch of the shoe, politicians in Mexico accused the designer, Willy Chavarria, and Adidas of cultural appropriation of artisan work. Designed by Willy Chavarria, the Adidas Oaxaca Slip-on model resembles a huarache, a traditional sandal manufactured by the Zapotec artisans of Oaxaca, Mexico. August 11, 2025 at

Willy Chavarria, American fashion designer, said he wanted to honor the Mexico culture when he created the Adidas Oaxaca Slip-on. The sandal has a thick black sole that Adidas used in a hiking shoe model that came out in the 1990s and a tissue black upper part that reminds that of an Oaxaca huarache, a traditional sandal manufactured by Zapotec artisans in Oaxaca, Mexico. "For me it is a hybrid between my work and Adidas, and it is like the perfect combination," said News Sneakers last week. "With white socks, it is literally one of the most classic Chicanas references." But when the model went on sale last week, some politicians in Mexico accused Chavarria and Adidas of "cultural appropriation." The president of Mexico, Claudia Sheinbaum, showed an image of the Adidas Oaxaca Slip-Ons sandals at her Friday press conference and said that Adidas and other companies were "usurping creativity" of indigenous communities. He said that the Oaxaca government had initiated conversations with Adidas to reimburse indigenous communities for the use of their "collective intellectual property" and that Mexico was willing to take legal actions. Chavarria, son of an Irish -American mother and Mexican -American father, issued an apology on Saturday, written in English and Spanish and addressed "to the people of Oaxaca." "The intention was always to honor the powerful cultural and artistic spirit of Oaxaca and its creative communities, a place whose beauty and resistance have inspired me," said Chavarria. "The name‘ Oaxaca ’is not just a word: it is living culture, it is people and is history." "I deeply regret that the shoe has appropriated this design and has not been developed in direct and significant collaboration with the Oaxaca community," he added. "This is not up to the respect and collaboration that Oaxaca, the Zapotec community of Villa Hidalgo Yalalag and their people deserve." Villa Hidalgo is an Oaxaca town where huaraches are manufactured. Adidas pointed out in a statement that "he recognizes and values the cultural wealth of the indigenous communities of Mexico and the meaning of his artisanal heritage." "The Oaxaca Slip-on was inspired by an Oaxaca design, rooted in the tradition of Villa Hidalgo Yalalag," said the company. "We offer a public apology and reaffirm our commitment to collaborate with Yalalag in a respectful dialogue that honors its cultural legacy." Chavarria said that "the intention was always to honor the powerful cultural and artistic spirit of Oaxaca and its creative communities." Adidas did not respond when asked if the sandal was still sold. Chavarria's work has often explored Mexico -American culture, sexuality and migration, based on their experience by growing in an agricultural community in California. His father was a migrant worker. Chavarria, who was Senior Vice President of Calvin Klein, told Sneaker News last week that she liked to work with great brands like Adidas because they helped him amplify his message of "human dignity." "It makes me very proud to work with a company that really respects and elevates the culture of the most genuine way," he said. Solomon Jara Cruz, governor of Oaxaca, said that sandal was a cultural "plagiarism. "The material and immaterial cultural heritage of our peoples has to be recognized and respected," he said on social networks. Mexican authorities have a jealous defense history of traditional designs against what they consider inappropriate uses by foreign. The Ministry of Culture of Mexico said in 2019 that it was surprised to discover that a colorful chair manufactured by the Fashion House Louis Vuitton included designs by Mexican artists from Hidalgo. In response, the brand said it was working with state artisans "with the prospect of collaborating together in the production of this collection." That same year, Alejandra Frausto, then Secretary of Culture of Mexico, wrote a letter to Carolina Herrera, the New York fashion brand, accusing her of using embroidery techniques and patterns of Mexican indigenous communities in the resort 2020 collection of the brand. The clothing line included floral and bird embroidery in dresses without straps, perforated leather coats and party dresses. In response, Wes Gordon, creative director of the brand, told The New York Times that the company was studying what measures to take. "We are living a great social change in the way of talking about gender, culture and identity," said Gordon. "They are important debates. We take it very seriously." Michael Levenson covers last minute news for the Times from New York.

translatedSummary: Adidas has apologized after Mexico criticized its shoe, the Adidas Oaxaca Slip-on, inspired by Huaraches de Oaxacas. The shoe was designed by Willy Chavarria and has been accused of cultural appropriation by Mexican politicians. The president of Mexico, Claudia Sheinbaum, stated that Adidas and other companies were "usurping creativity" of indigenous communities. Adidas defended the design, stating it was designed to honor the Mexico culture and its creative communities. scraped_sources.text:
Shoe releases come down to numbers, but cultural impact is immeasurable. adidas Originals is making all the waves across Latin America with its strategic partnerships and hyper-focused activations, choosing to enrich the community through heartfelt story-telling and design efforts that exude authenticity.
While much of the focus in adidas Originals’ weekend-long experience was on Bad Bunny, the colossal archive of sneakers, and the booming energy of Puerto Rico, Willy Chavarria briefly stole the spotlight by debuting his next collaboration with adidas.
Like the pointed and elongated Jabbar Lo that dropped earlier this year, the Oaxaca Slip-On nods to Chicano culture by taking inspiration from the moccasin sandal, a common piece of home-style fashion seen in Mexican households around the world. It features an intricate interlacing of leather strips on the upper, locked into a chunkified sole from the adidas SEEULATER, a 1990s era hiking sneaker/boot. White socks are surely a must with these.
Below are some shots of Willy at a special panel that was held at The Archive at the Museo de Arte de Puerto Rico where the Oaxaca Slip-On was first unveiled. Sneaker News spent time chatting with Willy to discuss not only his new sneaker, but his partnership with adidas Originals and how he continues to find inspiration.
“The message is really one of human dignity. That’s the bottom line.”
Willy Chavarria on his goals working with adidas Originals
John Kim: It’s been quite a year, good and bad, for people in the Latino culture. Can you describe what you’re feeling here in San Juan right now, and from a larger perspective?
Willy Chavarria: It’s amazing, it’s beautiful, and it’s incredible that all this is happening here in Puerto Rico. All of this is so incredible. And it’s also insane that at this time, the most horrific things are happening to Latinos in the United States that we’ve seen in a very, very long time. As great of a year as this is, it’s also really, really tough because of the challenges that our people are facing on a daily basis. So even at the start of this moment, of this administration, I immediately started talking with all of my friends and creative colleagues and you know all of us who are in this creative world about how important it is for us to make sure that we come together and really incorporate this message of unity and our strength and pride in our cultures.
Whether it’s making a film or working on a music thing with J Balvin or whatever it is, it’s really about the empowerment of people and really helping us to not only realize our own value but to show our value to the world. So what’s happening right now with this moment and Bad Bunny I think is incredibly important. The fact that Adidas is behind this says so much about the company and it makes me very proud to be working with a company that really respects and uplifts culture in the most real way.
“It’s like literally one of the most classic Chicano references with the white sock…”
Willy on Oaxaa Slip-On
As someone with Mexican heritage, what do you want to share with the world through your work and partnerships?
One of the reasons I do fashion and one of the reasons I partner with bigger brands like Adidas or even musicians is because I really believe that the larger the platform for my message, the better. And the message is really one of human dignity. That’s the bottom line. I celebrate Latino culture and celebrate queer culture because that’s like me. But at the end of the day, it’s about you and everyone in this room. It’s about human dignity. It’s about respecting and loving one another. And the more people that I can touch with that message, the better.
So when I think of my work with Adidas, what we’ll do together is really… focus more on how we can touch people in a personal level and spread that message. And I really hope to work with Adidas on touching people on more of a grassroots level. So going more into communities like this, going into Puerto Rico and doing something that’s actually for the people and not like in Hollywood or in New York where it’s like you invite only the select few to come and see, you know? I think that is the future. That is the future of fashion and that is the future of business.
“It makes me very proud to be working with a company that really respects and uplifts culture in the most real way.”
Willy on his partnership with adidas Originals
In that sense, storytelling and community are so important to launches like this.
Sneakers ARE fashion. Sneakers have such a greater purpose than they did back in the day. This to me is such a hybrid between my work and adidas and it’s just like the perfect combination, it’s like literally one of the most classic Chicano references with the white sock and it actually wasn’t easy to do…it took trial after trial after trial and it’s just really well made. The interior of the Huarache is fully padded. And the footbed is padded leather. And then it’s a SEEULATER bottom and it’s pumped up with some fancy foam. And yes, there’s a brown version coming too.
“Sneakers ARE fashion. Sneakers have such a greater purpose than they did back in the day.”
Willy on the importance of sneakers in 2025
What was the very first conversation with adidas like when you pitched the pointed toe Jabbar? Was there any hesitation?
Yeah. It took a minute. It took a minute for them to really get on board with it. But, I mean, it’s a big group of people. So, of course, there were some people that were like, oh, yeah, we got to do this. It’s amazing. And then there were some people that didn’t feel that way. But, you know, what’s great about the collaboration is it’s not a mass market. It’s really limited so it’s okay to take some risk in there.
The first one almost always has to be a risk.
Exactly. Yeah. You want to take that risk.
Do you feel a sense of responsibility, now that the partnership with adidas Originals will undeniably bring you to a larger audience?
I do. I do feel a responsibility. I think that anybody who has a career that is kind of public facing and is seen by a lot of people and starts to influence people has a responsibility. And my goal has been to really influence fashion and culture in a positive way, so along with that comes responsibility and I’m very grateful for it. I pray a lot. And this morning I was praying for giving thanks gratitude for this responsibility that I have and that I’m able to be in this space and really do something that’s positive. So I take it seriously, but I’m also very grateful for it.

argos_summary: Adidas faced backlash from Mexican officials over its Oaxaca slip-on shoe, designed by Willy Chavarria, which was accused of cultural appropriation of traditional Oaxacan huaraches. In response, both Chavarria and Adidas issued apologies, emphasizing their intention to honor the cultural heritage of Oaxaca and expressing a commitment to collaborate with local communities. The controversy highlights ongoing tensions regarding the use of indigenous designs by global brands.
